questions.questionsTitle: Explain the figure of speech inversion and anastrophe with example.

questions.questionsTitle: Write the Rhyming word and Scheme of the 1ststanza.

subQuestion.question: A pilgrim, going a lone high wayCame at evening, cold and grayTo a chasm, deep and vast and wide.The old man crossed in the twilight dim.The chasm held no fear for him.But he paused when he reached the other side And built a bridge to span the tide.
subQuestion.ans: Rhyming word =way - gray / wide-side - tide / dim - him.AABCCBB is called the Rhyme Scheme of the 1ststanza of the poem 'The Pilgrim'.

questions.questionsTitle: Write the Rhyming word and Scheme of the 2ndstanza.

subQuestion.question: "Old man," said a fellow pilgrim near,"Why waste your time in building here?Your journey ends with the close of the day You never again will pass this way.You have crossed the chasm deep and wide Why build ye here at even tide?"
subQuestion.ans: Rhyming word =near - here / day - way / Wide - Tide.AABBCC is called the Rhyme Scheme of the2ndstanza of the poem 'The Pilgrim'.

questions.questionsTitle: Write the Rhyming word and Scheme of the 3rdstanza.

subQuestion.question: The pilgrim raised his old gray head,"My friend in the path I've come," he said, "There followeth after me todayA fair haired youth, who must pass this way. The chasm which held no fears for meTo the fair haired youth, may a pitfall be.He, too, must cross in the twilight dim.My friend, I am building this bridge for him."
subQuestion.ans: Rhyming words =head - said / Today - way / me - be / dim - him.AABBCCDD is called the Rhyme Scheme of the 3rdstanza of the poem 'The Pilgrim'.

subQuestion.ans: It not only loosens and turns up the soil, it converts garbage into organic fertilizer too.

subQuestion.question: Introduction of the topic

subQuestion.question: Body of the Speech

subQuestion.question: Conclusion
subQuestion.ans: Dragonflies and spiders keep down the insect population by eating insects.

subQuestion.question: Expression of gratitude to audience

questions.questionsTitle: Name the festival that you enjoy most of all. Fill in the facts about that festival.

subQuestion.question: Name of the festival:
subQuestion.ans: Name of the festival:Diwali

subQuestion.question: When it is celebrated:
subQuestion.ans: When it is celebrated:It is celebrated every autumn between October and November.

subQuestion.question: Why it is celebrated:
subQuestion.ans:
Why it is celebrated:Diwali is a holiday in South India celebrating the day that Lord Krishna killed the demon Narakasura.
In northern India, rows of clay lamps are lit in honor of the tale of King Rama's return to Ayodhya following his victory over Ravana.

subQuestion.question: How it is celebrated:
subQuestion.ans:
How it is celebrated:Along with their homes and places of employment, people also clean and decorate temples.
Candles and oil lamps are used to brighten the surroundings, and devotional offerings, or puja, are made.
Additionally, people frequently wear jewellery and brand-new, elegant clothing or cleanse themselves with water and aromatic oils.
Families may plan feasts where gifts and sweets (mithai) are exchanged.
Many towns, cities, and villages host fairs (melas) and light fireworks in the evening.

subQuestion.question: Special cuisine:
subQuestion.ans: Special cuisine:Samosa, aloo bunda, gulab jamun, sooji halwa, murukku, namak pare, gajar ka halwa, gujiya, kalakand, batasha, rasgulla, soan papdi, etc.

subQuestion.question: Other special features:
subQuestion.ans: Other special features:People dress to the nines, light fireworks, worship Lakshmi, the goddess of riches and prosperity, light diyas and rangoli to light up the inside and outside of their homes, and give gifts and mithai (sweets) during family feasts during Diwali.

questions.questionsTitle: State the facts about the story.

subQuestion.question: Main characters:
subQuestion.ans: Main characters:Sue, Johnsy, the doctor, and Behrman.

subQuestion.question: Problem:
subQuestion.ans: Problem:Johnsy's negative attitude, her lack of will to live, and the fancy that she would die when the last leaf fell from the ivy vine.

subQuestion.question: Attempts made to solve it:
subQuestion.ans:
Attempts made to solve it:The doctor informed Sue that Johnsy would recover only if she had the wish to live.
Sue looked after her well and tried to make her think positively.
Finally, Behrman painted a leaf on the wall so that the last leaf would never fall, and Johnsy would live.

subQuestion.question: Climax/Turning point:
subQuestion.ans:
Climax/Turning point:(i) When Johnsy sees the last leaf still clinging to the vine, and realizes that she has been given a message that she was wicked to want to die.
(ii) The sweeper finding Behrman in very wet clothes and shoes, with scattered brushes and a palette with yellow and green colours mixed on it.

subQuestion.question: Problem solved:
subQuestion.ans: Problem solved:Johnsy realizes her mistake and begins to look forward to life again.

subQuestion.question: End:
subQuestion.ans:
End:Though Johnsy lives, Behrman, who painted the last leaf, contracts pneumonia due to exposure to rain and snow.
He dies due to his efforts.
He dies so that Johnsy lives.

questions.questionsTitle: Read the descriptions of the following from the story and describe any one of them using your own words.

subQuestion.question: The ivy vine
subQuestion.ans:
The ivy vine- Outside the window there was an old ivy vine, gnarled and decayed at the roots.
It had climbed half way up the brick wall.
It had lost most of its leaves due to the cold autumn.
Only a few bare branches were left, clinging to the bricks.

subQuestion.question: Behrman
subQuestion.ans:
Behrman- Behrman was a struggling painter who lived on the ground floor of the building where Sue and Johnsy lived.He was a failure in art, for though he had been painting for forty years, he had not made any money.
He always dreamt about painting a masterpiece, and often spoke about it, but had never got round to doing it.
He served as a model for the young artists in the colony, who could not afford other models.
He was shocked when he heard about Johnsy's fancy and thought that the place was not good for her.
He was a generous, compassionate, and kindhearted man.
Even though he was old, he braved the wind, rain, and snow to go out and paint the last leaf on the wall.
He died in order that Johnsy could live.

subQuestion.question: The last leaf that Johnsy saw
subQuestion.ans:
The last leaf that Johnsy saw:The last leaf that Johnsy saw was not a real leaf but a leaf painted on the wall by Behrman.
It was dark green near its stem, but its edges were tinted with yellow.
It hung from a branch some twenty feet above the ground.
Naturally, it never fluttered or moved when the wind blew.
It was Behrman's masterpiece and had been painted the night when the real last leaf had fallen.

questions.questionsTitle: State the facts about the story.

subQuestion.question: Main characters:
subQuestion.ans: Main characters:Sue, Johnsy, the doctor, and Behrman.

subQuestion.question: Problem:
subQuestion.ans: Problem:Johnsy's negative attitude, her lack of will to live, and the fancy that she would die when the last leaf fell from the ivy vine.

subQuestion.question: Attempts made to solve it:
subQuestion.ans:
Attempts made to solve it:The doctor informed Sue that Johnsy would recover only if she had the wish to live.
Sue looked after her well and tried to make her think positively.
Finally, Behrman painted a leaf on the wall so that the last leaf would never fall, and Johnsy would live.

subQuestion.question: Climax/Turning point:
subQuestion.ans:
Climax/Turning point:(i) When Johnsy sees the last leaf still clinging to the vine, and realizes that she has been given a message that she was wicked to want to die.
(ii) The sweeper finding Behrman in very wet clothes and shoes, with scattered brushes and a palette with yellow and green colours mixed on it.

subQuestion.question: Problem solved:
subQuestion.ans: Problem solved:Johnsy realizes her mistake and begins to look forward to life again.

subQuestion.question: End:
subQuestion.ans:
End:Though Johnsy lives, Behrman, who painted the last leaf, contracts pneumonia due to exposure to rain and snow.
He dies due to his efforts.
He dies so that Johnsy lives.

questions.questionsTitle: Read the descriptions of the following from the story and describe any one of them using your own words.

subQuestion.question: The ivy vine
subQuestion.ans:
The ivy vine- Outside the window there was an old ivy vine, gnarled and decayed at the roots.
It had climbed half way up the brick wall.
It had lost most of its leaves due to the cold autumn.
Only a few bare branches were left, clinging to the bricks.

subQuestion.question: Behrman
subQuestion.ans:
Behrman- Behrman was a struggling painter who lived on the ground floor of the building where Sue and Johnsy lived.He was a failure in art, for though he had been painting for forty years, he had not made any money.
He always dreamt about painting a masterpiece, and often spoke about it, but had never got round to doing it.
He served as a model for the young artists in the colony, who could not afford other models.
He was shocked when he heard about Johnsy's fancy and thought that the place was not good for her.
He was a generous, compassionate, and kindhearted man.
Even though he was old, he braved the wind, rain, and snow to go out and paint the last leaf on the wall.
He died in order that Johnsy could live.

subQuestion.question: The last leaf that Johnsy saw
subQuestion.ans:
The last leaf that Johnsy saw:The last leaf that Johnsy saw was not a real leaf but a leaf painted on the wall by Behrman.
It was dark green near its stem, but its edges were tinted with yellow.
It hung from a branch some twenty feet above the ground.
Naturally, it never fluttered or moved when the wind blew.
It was Behrman's masterpiece and had been painted the night when the real last leaf had fallen.

subQuestion.question: Characters:
subQuestion.ans: Characters:Krishnadevaraya, Mantriji, Tenali Raman, Pundit Shahane, 8-10 other courtiers/ministers/scholars.

subQuestion.question: Background Scene:
subQuestion.ans:
Background Scene:Krishnadevaraya's Courtroom.
The Emperor is seated on his throne.
Courtiers/ministers/scholars are seated in two rows facing one another and discussing softly.

subQuestion.question: Crisis:
subQuestion.ans:
Crisis:A great scholarly Pundit, Pundit Shahane, has challenged the knowledge of the Pundits of Vijaynagar.
The Pundits of Vijaynagar are not ready to face this challenge.

subQuestion.question: Steps taken to resolve the crisis:
subQuestion.ans: Steps taken to resolve the crisis:Tenali Raman is sent for to find a solution to the predicament and to pull them out of the tight corner.

subQuestion.question: Climax:
subQuestion.ans: Climax:Tenali Raman, with his sheer wit, manages to outwit the renowned Pundit Shahane and make him concede defeat.

subQuestion.question: The end:
subQuestion.ans:
The end:Pundit Shahane concedes defeat and leaves.
Tenali Raman is praised by the Emperor for saving the reputation and honour of the great empire.
Everyone is relieved and happy that the crisis has ended.

questions.questionsTitle: Explain the figure of speech tautology with example.

subQuestion.question: Explain the figure of speech tautology with example.
subQuestion.ans: If two or more words in the same line convey the same meaning, the Figure of Speech in that line is calledTautology.For example, It broughtjoyandcheer.They groaned withachesandpains.

questions.questionsTitle: Explain the figure of speech inversion and anastrophe with example.

subQuestion.question: Explain the figure of speech inversion and anastrophe with example.
subQuestion.ans: Poets often change the proper grammatical order of words in the line of a poem, in order to make the lines rhyme or to emphasize upon something.The Figure of Speech in such lines is called 'Inversion' or 'Anastrophe.'For example, Up came the sun.

questions.questionsTitle: Write the Rhyming word and Scheme of the 1ststanza.

subQuestion.question: A pilgrim, going a lone high wayCame at evening, cold and grayTo a chasm, deep and vast and wide.The old man crossed in the twilight dim.The chasm held no fear for him.But he paused when he reached the other side And built a bridge to span the tide.

questions.questionsTitle: Write the Rhyming word and Scheme of the 3rdstanza.

subQuestion.question: The pilgrim raised his old gray head,"My friend in the path I've come," he said, "There followeth after me todayA fair haired youth, who must pass this way. The chasm which held no fears for meTo the fair haired youth, may a pitfall be.He, too, must cross in the twilight dim.My friend, I am building this bridge for him."

questions.questionsTitle: Name the festival that you enjoy most of all. Fill in the facts about that festival.

subQuestion.question: Name of the festival:
subQuestion.ans: Name of the festival:Diwali

subQuestion.question: When it is celebrated:
subQuestion.ans: When it is celebrated:It is celebrated every autumn between October and November.

subQuestion.question: Why it is celebrated:
subQuestion.ans:
Why it is celebrated:Diwali is a holiday in South India celebrating the day that Lord Krishna killed the demon Narakasura.
In northern India, rows of clay lamps are lit in honor of the tale of King Rama's return to Ayodhya following his victory over Ravana.

subQuestion.question: How it is celebrated:
subQuestion.ans:
How it is celebrated:Along with their homes and places of employment, people also clean and decorate temples.
Candles and oil lamps are used to brighten the surroundings, and devotional offerings, or puja, are made.
Additionally, people frequently wear jewellery and brand-new, elegant clothing or cleanse themselves with water and aromatic oils.
Families may plan feasts where gifts and sweets (mithai) are exchanged.
Many towns, cities, and villages host fairs (melas) and light fireworks in the evening.

subQuestion.question: Special cuisine:
subQuestion.ans: Special cuisine:Samosa, aloo bunda, gulab jamun, sooji halwa, murukku, namak pare, gajar ka halwa, gujiya, kalakand, batasha, rasgulla, soan papdi, etc.

subQuestion.question: Other special features:
subQuestion.ans: Other special features:People dress to the nines, light fireworks, worship Lakshmi, the goddess of riches and prosperity, light diyas and rangoli to light up the inside and outside of their homes, and give gifts and mithai (sweets) during family feasts during Diwali.
